inception1_start.speaker: steve
inception1_start.dialogue: (So, it's 5am already. I need a coffee, because the end of my shift is still a long way off...)

inception1_01.dialogue: Hello! FBI Special Agent Harrison here.

inception1_02.dialogue: Steve Harrison. This is FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover speaking.
inception1_02.speaker: director

inception1_04.dialogue: This is not a phone call. Come to my office immediately!
inception1_04.speaker: director

inception2_start.speaker: director
inception2_start.dialogue: Come in and have a seat.

inception2_02.dialogue: Despite the early hour, I have a very important task for you.

inception2_04.dialogue: You need to help your country! The life of the entire planet depends on your work!
inception2_04.speaker: director

inception2_05.dialogue: Always ready, sir! What is my assignment?
inception2_05.speaker: steve

inception2_06.dialogue: A group of hackers led by Kevin Mitnick created a virus.
inception2_06.speaker: director

inception2_07.dialogue: It is capable of erasing all data from the computer's memory, making failure of the world wide web.

inception2_08.dialogue: It is distributed via a regular message.

inception2_09.dialogue: Information security specialist Sarah Parker's computer was hacked last night.

inception2_10.dialogue: Files were stolen from it, and this virus was launched into the network.

inception2_11.dialogue: We have less than 20 hours left to create an antivirus.

inception2_12.dialogue: If we don't create an antivirus on Prolog, then there will be global chaos.

inception2_13.dialogue: There will be planes crashing and spaceships deorbiting.

inception2_14.dialogue: We also learned that Sarah Parker was kidnapped from her home the night before.

inception2_15.dialogue: Her whereabouts are unknown to us at this time...

inception2_16.dialogue: But we were able to locate the very computer that we need to inject the antivirus into.

inception2_17.dialogue: I understand you, sir. However, there is a small nuance...
inception2_17.speaker: steve

inception2_18.dialogue: I'm not too familiar with the Prolog language...

inception2_19.dialogue: You are the best expert in computer security. You are our best agent.
inception2_19.speaker: director

inception2_20.dialogue: You are the fastest to learn new things. You can solve any riddle!

inception2_21.dialogue: We know about your merits, Steve!

inception2_22.dialogue: All the operations you participated in, you did it perfectly!

inception2_23.dialogue: I personally called you to my office

inception2_24.dialogue: because I can only entrust such an important mission to you.

inception2_25.dialogue: The life of the entire planet is at stake!

inception2_27.dialogue: I'll try to figure it all out. I will not let you down, sir!

inception2_28.dialogue: Always be one step ahead of your enemies...
inception2_28.speaker: director

inception2_29.dialogue: Just one mistake can destroy everything we have worked so hard to create.

inception2_30.dialogue: The car that will take you to that very mansion is waiting at the entrance.

inception2_34.dialogue: There are life-threatening traps everywhere in this abandoned mansion.

inception2_35.dialogue: You need to enter the correct code to secure them.

inception2_36.dialogue: I believe in you. Call me anytime. Good luck!

inception3_01.speaker: anonymous
inception3_01.dialogue: Stop! Who goes there?! Stop, living creature!

inception3_02.dialogue: You are wandering in these places in vain! Such creatures are forbidden to walk here!

inception3_05.dialogue: I'm calling the police, there are bandits here, help!

inception3_06.speaker: steve
inception3_06.dialogue: I am the police! FBI Agent Steve Harrison.

inception3_07.speaker: robot
inception3_07.dialogue: Oh, hello, Agent Steve Harrison. You should have put away your weapons.

inception3_08.dialogue: I just thought that looters had come, I thought they would try to break down the door again. Because no one can enter the correct code.

inception3_10.dialogue: And I'm just a third-generation robot, model R3.

inception3_11.dialogue: I shouldn't let anyone alive in here, because no one knows about the death traps.

inception3_12.dialogue: Why are you here, Agent Harrison?

inception3_14.dialogue: So you are a robot model R3, this is a robot -- a human assistant.

inception3_15.dialogue: You strictly observe the three laws.

inception3_16.dialogue: Your duties include listening and helping any person. Is that right?

inception3_18.dialogue: A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.

inception3_19.dialogue: A robot must obey the orders of human beings except in cases where that would conflict with the First Law.

inception3_20.speaker: steve
inception3_20.dialogue: Great, then you'll help me. Listen carefully!

inception3_21.dialogue: Kevin Mitnick has created a virus that can erase all data from a computer's memory and cause the World Wide Web to malfunction. And already launched it.

inception3_23.dialogue: Less than 18 hours left to create an antivirus in Prolog.

inception3_24.dialogue: Will you help me study it?

inception3_25.speaker: robot
inception3_25.dialogue: Yes, I have such a function programmed.

inception3_26.dialogue: But you should know that in order to learn Prolog, you need to move away from the usual forms of programming.

inception3_28.dialogue: Try to understand the logic of the language itself. Believe me, it is a pretty and logical language.

inception3_29.dialogue: Very soon you will appreciate all its beauty and possibilities.

inception3_30.speaker: steve
inception3_30.dialogue: I have no doubt about it. Shall we move on to the lesson already?

inception3_31.speaker: robot
inception3_31.dialogue: Let's get started! I have a tablet that you can use to learn more about the Prolog language. It can help you with the assignments.

inception3_32.speaker: steve
inception3_32.dialogue: Can I familiarize myself with the theory?

inception4_start.speaker: robot
inception4_start.dialogue: A Prolog program consists of a set of sentences. Each of them can be one of three types: it is either a fact, a rule, or a query.

inception4_01.dialogue: A fact is a phrase without conditions, a statement that some relation holds.

inception4_02.speaker: steve
inception4_02.dialogue: Every fact must end with a period. For example: `likes('Steve', work).`

inception4_03.dialogue: A rule is a fact whose truth depends on the truth of other facts. It consists of a head and a body, separated by the `:-` sign - the "if" operator, the inverse implication.

inception4_04.dialogue: The head of a rule is a predicate, and the body of a rule is a sequence of predicates separated by commas.

inception4_05.speaker: steve
inception4_05.dialogue:
A rule must end with a period.
For example: `likes(steve, X) :- likes(robot, X)`.

inception4_06.dialogue: A query is a sequence of predicates separated by commas or semicolons and ending with a period.

inception4_07.dialogue: The comma `,` matches the conjunction "and", and in in mathematical logic denotes conjunction.

inception4_08.dialogue: The semicolon `;` corresponds to the conjunction "or" and denotes disjunction. The query predicate is called the target.

inception4_09.speaker: steve
inception4_09.dialogue: Got it, got it, I'll solve it now!

inception4_10.speaker: robot
inception4_10.dialogue: Be careful. Make too many mistakes and you won't be able to continue.

inception4_failTask0_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And take care of your health. You seem to be getting nervous...

inception4_failTask0_03.dialogue: Focus, agent! This is your last attempt...

inception4_13.dialogue: ...Okay. I see it's time to continue our journey... and our learning.

elaboration1_start.speaker: steve
elaboration1_start.dialogue: First task completed successfully! Didn't even expect it to happen so quickly!

elaboration1_02.dialogue: I must admit that you are very smart and resourceful! I am very happy for you!
elaboration1_02.speaker: robot

elaboration1_03.dialogue: I received a call from the director. Yes, sir!
elaboration1_03.speaker: steve

elaboration1_04.dialogue: Special Agent Steve Harrison, this is the FBI Director. I have urgent news for you!
elaboration1_04.speaker: director

elaboration1_05.dialogue: We have tracked Kevin Mitnick's location. He is somewhere in the house. Be careful! He may have a weapon!

elaboration1_06.dialogue: I understand. Any new information about Sarah Parker has not appeared?
elaboration1_06.speaker: steve

elaboration1_07.dialogue: We have questioned all the people involved in the case, but no one saw or heard anything. It was as if she disappeared into thin air.
elaboration1_07.speaker: director

elaboration1_08.dialogue: There is a feeling that Mitnick keeps her somewhere near him...
elaboration1_08.speaker: steve

elaboration1_09.dialogue: You will also have to work out this version. Good luck! You have an important mission!
elaboration1_09.speaker: director

elaboration1_10.dialogue: How dark and gloomy it is here! But we can't hesitate. If Mitnick is somewhere in the house, then Sarah should be nearby. Let's go upstairs!
elaboration1_10.speaker: steve

elaboration1_11.dialogue: Be careful going up, sir! There are traps hidden in some of the steps. These are the next tasks...
elaboration1_11.speaker: robot

elaboration1_12.dialogue: Now I'll look at the theory.
elaboration1_12.speaker: robot

elaboration1_13.dialogue: The arguments of a Prolog program's statements are called terms, and the Prolog program itself can be viewed as a network of relations between terms.
elaboration1_13.speaker: steve

elaboration1_14.dialogue: Each term denotes an object of the subject area and is written as a sequence of letters from these categories: uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers and special characters.

elaboration1_15.dialogue: There are usually three types of terms as the main data objects: constants, variables (simple terms) and structures (compound terms).

elaboration1_16.dialogue:
A constant is a named concrete object or a concrete relationship.
For example: `steve`.

elaboration1_17.dialogue: A variable is an object whose value changes during program execution. A variable name begins with an uppercase letter or an underscore. For example: `Who`, `_who`.

elaboration1_18.dialogue: A variable is called bound if there is an object that it denotes. In the absence of such an object, the variable is called free.

elaboration1_19.dialogue:
A structure is an object consisting of a set of components - other objects. For example:
`likes("Steve", book ("Name", "Author")).`

elaboration1_20.dialogue: I learned a lot of new things for myself...now let's move on to the task, because there is little time...
elaboration1_20.speaker: steve

elaboration1_failTask1_01.dialogue: Be more careful, agent! I told you, tasks are traps.
elaboration1_failTask1_01.speaker: robot

elaboration2_start.speaker: steve
elaboration2_start.dialogue: Another trap! The door is locked again... You need to enter a code here too.

elaboration2_01.dialogue: You've already completed 2 tasks! Don't lose heart, sir!
elaboration2_01.speaker: robot

elaboration2_02.dialogue: I think I hear some sounds coming from under that door! It feels like there's someone there!
elaboration2_02.speaker: steve

elaboration2_04.dialogue: Me too! But the worst thing is not being able to complete all the tasks in 6 hours!
elaboration2_04.speaker: steve

elaboration2_05.dialogue: Yeah, better get to the next task!
elaboration2_05.speaker: robot

elaboration2_06.dialogue: Prolog is a logic-based language. The basic blocks are facts, rules, and queries.

elaboration2_07.dialogue: They allow you to describe knowledge and perform logical inference.

elaboration2_08.dialogue: Simple queries that do not contain any variables allow two possible answers: `true` or `false`.

elaboration2_09.dialogue: If the answer is `true`, the query is said to have been successful and the goal has been achieved.
elaboration2_09.speaker: steve

elaboration2_10.dialogue: Using variables in queries allows you to ask more complex questions.
elaboration2_10.speaker: steve

elaboration2_11.dialogue:
For example:
`?- likes('Steve','book').` returns `true`.
`?- likes(Who,'book').` returns `Who = 'Steve'`.
elaboration2_11.speaker: steve

elaboration2_12.dialogue: So let's try to apply the theory to practice.
elaboration2_12.speaker: steve

elaboration2_15.dialogue: You're making progress, agent. It's time to open the room...

elaboration3_start.speaker: steve
elaboration3_start.dialogue: Wow, who would have thought that such a house could have such a cozy office.

elaboration3_01.dialogue: I have a feeling that someone was here recently, even left some papers on the table.

elaboration3_02.dialogue: A very nice and cute room.
elaboration3_02.speaker: robot

elaboration3_03.dialogue: But there is no computer here, so we will have to look further. Mitnick must have been here just recently.
elaboration3_03.speaker: steve

elaboration3_07.dialogue: Maybe Mitnick decided to return to his office?
elaboration3_07.speaker: steve

elaboration3_08.dialogue: I'll hide under the table so no one will notice me. Ouch, ouch, ouch... another hidden trap.
elaboration3_08.speaker: steve

elaboration3_09.dialogue: I accidentally touched some mechanism and found myself in a trap. Metal bars came down on me from all sides....
elaboration3_09.speaker: steve

elaboration3_11.dialogue: Here you need to complete another task and enter the code. This is the only way to free yourself.
elaboration3_11.speaker: robot

elaboration3_12.dialogue: I agree, the bars are too strong... And plus, anyone can get in here! We need to complete the task quickly.
elaboration3_12.speaker: steve

elaboration3_14.dialogue: Okay, let's look at the theory. Oh, no! Nothing is said here for the next task...
elaboration3_14.speaker: steve

elaboration3_15.dialogue: Hah, and Mitnik is cunning, but let's not be sad, let's try our hand.
elaboration3_15.speaker: steve

elaboration3_17.dialogue: Okay... Looks like the trap is deactivated.

elaboration4_start.speaker: steve
elaboration4_start.dialogue: Wow! It worked! I got out of the trap. Now we need to quickly go and find the computer!

elaboration4_02.dialogue: Do you hear those strange sounds again? There's definitely someone here!
elaboration4_02.speaker: steve

elaboration4_03.dialogue: It sounds like some kind of mooing. The sounds are coming from that far corner.
elaboration4_03.speaker: robot

elaboration4_04.dialogue: Let's see what's in there! It looks like there really is someone there!
elaboration4_04.speaker: steve

elaboration4_05.dialogue: It's the kidnapped information security specialist Sarah Parker!
elaboration4_05.speaker: steve

elaboration4_06.dialogue: I'm FBI Special Agent Steve Harrison. Tell me what happened to you...
elaboration4_06.speaker: steve

elaboration4_07.dialogue: Kevin Mitnick kidnapped me from my home last night! He's gone crazy and he needs to be stopped immediately!
elaboration4_07.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_08.dialogue: Help me get free, please! I know where the main computer is!

elaboration4_09.dialogue: You're a brave girl! Now I'll complete the task, enter the code and we'll free you! Don't worry!
elaboration4_09.speaker: steve

elaboration4_10.dialogue: Now I'll look at the tablet, get acquainted with the theory...

elaboration4_11.dialogue: Lists are an important structure. Lists allow you to store an arbitrary amount of data.

elaboration4_12.dialogue: A node contains data and a link (pointer, link) to one or two neighboring nodes.

elaboration4_13.dialogue: Prolog lists are simply linked, each node contains one link.

elaboration4_14.dialogue: There are built-in functions for working with lists, let's look at some of them.

elaboration4_15.dialogue: `sum_list(List, Sum)` — calculating the sum of the elements of a list

elaboration4_16.dialogue: `member(Elem, List)` — checks if such an element is in the list.

elaboration4_18.dialogue: `length(List, Length)` — calculates the length of the list.

elaboration4_20.dialogue: `delete(InputList, Elem, ResultList)` — removes all elements with a given value from the list, returning a new list.

elaboration4_21.dialogue: Yes, this will be more complicated, but we are there. We can handle it!

elaboration5_start.speaker: steve
elaboration5_start.dialogue: There! We're almost there! And here's the computer... It's not a supercomputer, but it's still a pretty powerful machine!

elaboration5_01.dialogue: Look, the computer is on and downloading some files. Let's see what's in there?
elaboration5_01.speaker: sarah

elaboration5_02.dialogue: There's a whole list of encrypted personal data of US Mint employees. As far as I know, only 10 of them have access to the Fort Knox vault.
elaboration5_02.speaker: steve

elaboration5_03.dialogue: To get inside the vault, each of them must enter their part of the code and then 'sim-sim' will open its doors.
elaboration5_03.speaker: steve

elaboration5_04.dialogue: And he does this extremely rarely. In the entire history of Fort Knox, only three times have outsiders entered it.
elaboration5_04.speaker: steve

elaboration5_05.dialogue: Who was given this honor? How did they manage to get in there?
elaboration5_05.speaker: sarah

elaboration5_06.dialogue: The first person to enter there was President Roosevelt in 1943. The reserves were checked for the second time only 31 years later.
elaboration5_06.speaker: steve

elaboration5_07.dialogue: And the third inspection took place in 2018, as rumors began to circulate that there was no gold in the vault.
elaboration5_07.speaker: steve

elaboration5_08.dialogue: However, this turned out to be just rumors, all the gold was in place.
elaboration5_08.speaker: steve

elaboration5_09.dialogue: I wonder if the mint employees are also in the house with Mitnik or does he want to use them in the dark?
elaboration5_09.speaker: sarah

elaboration5_10.dialogue: We will definitely find out later, but now we need to stop the virus and enter the code before anyone interferes with us.
elaboration5_10.speaker: steve

elaboration5_12.dialogue: Now I'll reveal the theory... Again, it's not there, but last time we managed.

lose_start.speaker: anonymous
lose_start.dialogue: 2... 1... 0... Uploading `virus.pl` to the network has been successfully completed.

lose_1.speaker: steve
lose_1.dialogue: Damn... Shouldn't have wasted all those attempts.

lose_2.dialogue: All that's left to do is call the director and warn him to get his specialists involved.

lose_3.dialogue: Maybe they can do something... Although it's unlikely.

win_start.speaker: anonymous
win_start.dialogue: 12... 11... 10... Are you sure you want to stop loading `virus.pl`?

win_6.speaker: steve
win_6.dialogue: Great! Now it's time to enter antivirus in case Mitnick tries to retry the download.

win_7.dialogue: And then you need to get out of here.

limbo_2.dialogue: During your adventure, you somehow passed out.

limbo_3.dialogue: Alas, although it is not your fault...

limbo_4.dialogue: My virus has already been launched into the network and is currently penetrating billions of devices.

limbo_5.dialogue: You're late, Steven! I am now a certified ruler of this world.

task0.questionText: Which of the following is basic element of Prolog when working with knowledge bases?

task2.questionText: Is it possible to use variables (like `X`) in rules (see below)? ```develop(X) :- work(X, virus).```

task3.questionText:
The following facts:```character(professor).
character(steve).
character(mitnik).```What is the result of the query `character(steve).`?
task3.hint: Think about what a fact is.

task4.questionText: How can I find the length of the list `[a, b, c, d]` in Prolog?

Write a query to return all characters in one query:```character(professor).
character(steve).
character(vicky).```Save the query result in the `Who` variable
(the variable should store one character).
